Using Rally Applications
This help message contains information on how to use the main menu and form/reports of a Rally application.
Using the Application Main Menu
Use this menu to choose the part of the application on which you are going to work. The menu consists of:
o The menu prompt: this is the first line of the menu. The prompt contains menu information that helps you make the proper choice.
o The response area: this is the second line of the menu. This line is the home area for the cursor and contains the } indicator. Enter your choice on this line.
o The menu choice area: this occupies the rest of the main menu and includes the names of the choices available to you.
Making Choices from the Menu
You can select a menu choice in one of the following ways:
o Moving the cursor. Use the arrow keys to move to the choice you want to select. The choice on which the cursor rests is highlighted in reverse video. When you have moved the cursor to the choice you want, press RETURN.
o Typing the full name of the choice. Type the full name of the choice you select in the response area of the menu, immediately after the } indicator, then press RETURN.
o Typing enough letters to uniquely identify your choice. Type two or more letters of your choice on the response area immediately after the }, then press RETURN.
Exiting the Main Menu
You exit from the main menu by selecting EXIT as your choice. Use one of the selection methods described above.
Using Rally Commands
Use Rally commands:
o To move around in, and between, forms, reports, and menus
o To enter and modify data on a form/report
o To commit (save) the changes you made
o To rollback (erase) the changes you made
o To make queries about data
o To print or write reports, parts of reports, or screens to a file
o To make menu choices
o To change the size and location of windows on the screen
o To move between tasks and actions in the application
o To move from a Rally application back to the environment you entered the application from without ending your Rally session
o To leave the Rally application
Invoke Rally commands in one of two ways:
o Use the Rally command line. To reach this command line, press GOLD-KP7 or the DO key. When the command line appears, type the name of the command on the line and press RETURN.
You need enter only enough of the command to make it unique among commands. When the command has more than one word, enter enough of each word to make it unique. For example, to invoke the 'delete record' command, you could enter "del reco". When words of a command are connected by an underscore, you can treat the two words as one word. For example, you can invoke the 'insert record next_group' command by typing "ins rec nex" on the command line.
o Press a predefined key that invokes a command. Rally provides two sets of key assignments: WPS-style (the default) and EDT-style. Someone on your system may have made additions or refinements to these key assignments.
Online help is available for Rally commands. The online help contains the following information about each Rally command:
o WPS-style and EDT-style key assignments for the command
o A description of its function
o An example of its use, if necessary
o Its alias (this information is provided for application developers)
Online help also contains two tables that list all the commands and their WPS-style or EDT-style key assignments.
To get help on a Rally command, follow these steps:
1. Press GOLD-KP7 or the DO key to activate the command line.
2. Press GOLD-H.
3. Help on commands is in a menu format. Select the menu choices that lead to the command you want help on. You can also look at only command-to-key assignments by selecting choice 9 from the command help main menu.
4. Read the help for the command. Use the following keys to move around in the help message:
RETURN Exits the current help message GOLD-X Enlarges the help window to the size of the screen GOLD-B Moves to the bottom of the help message GOLD-T Moves to the top of the help message NEXT SCREEN Moves down one page. The size of a page is determined by the size of the window PREV SCREEN Moves up one page
Press RETURN to leave the help message and return to the command help menu. From there, you can return to the command line.
If you want to leave the command line without entering a command, press GOLD-Q.
Using Form/Reports
Use form/reports to display, enter, or retrieve data.
Entering Data
Enter data by typing information in fields. Move forward from field to field by pressing the RETURN key. Move backward from field to field by pressing the BACKSPACE key.
Use text-editing keys to make changes in the values that you enter.
How to Exit a Form/Report
To leave the form/report and commit any changes you have made, use GOLD-F.
To prevent a change from being made, use GOLD-Q.
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Enter one of the selection criteria listed below, enter a value, and press RETURN. An asterisk (*) appears in the field for which you have entered extended query selection criteria. Enter the values as you would enter data in the field. Therefore, if the field has an input format, use that format.
The selection criteria are as follows:
EQ or = NE or {} LT or { GT or } LE or {= GE or }= CONTAINS MATCHES STARTS AND, OR NOT
CONTAINS, MATCHES, and STARTS can be abbreviated to as few as a single character each.
Within a field, the extended query can make use of AND, NOT, and OR. Queries in multiple fields are connected by implicit AND statements.
Examples of valid extended queries are:
ST B = RED OR = WHITE NOT MA *lamp*
If you wish to remove an extended query already present for this field, use the 'delete line' command and press RETURN.

Repeat

Finish Application
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Ends an application. If the application involves data entry, the 'finish application' command saves all data that you typed. This command stops all tasks that are currently running and returns you to the environment from which you entered RALLY. For example, the operating system command line or an application can call RALLY.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Sets the query criteria for a form/report to those of the most recent successful query performed on that form/report. You can make modifications to these query criteria and execute the modified query with the execute query command to simplify repetitive querying.

Undelete Record After
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Inserts a new record after the current record in the current group, and then implicitly performs a 'recall record' command to fill in all the values for fields in the new record. These values are derived from record values obtained from a previous 'delete record' or 'copy record' command executed in the current group. The record values are re-inserted when you move the cursor off the new record.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Undelete Record Before
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-REMOVE EDT: GOLD-REMOVE
Inserts a new record before the current record in the current group, then implicitly performs a recall record command to fill in all the values for fields in the new record. These values are derived from record values obtained from a previous 'delete record' or 'copy record' command executed in the current group. The record values are re-inserted when you move the cursor off the new record.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Undelete Record Next_group
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Inserts a new record in the next group of a form/report, then implicitly performs a recall record command to fill in all the values for fields in the new record. These values are derived from record values obtained from a previous 'delete record' or 'copy record' command executed in that group. The record values are re-inserted when you move the cursor off the new record.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Recall Record
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Inserts a copy of the contents of the record buffer into the current record. To use the 'recall record' command, you must first either delete a record, or use the 'copy record' command, to place a record in the record buffer.
The 'recall record' command issues an error message if the current group does not allow modification of records, if no record has been deleted or copied in the current group, or if the form/report is read only.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Copy Record
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Copies the field values of a form/report record to the record buffer. Before issuing this command, you must position the cursor somewhere in the record you want to copy.
After you have used the 'copy record' command to put a value in the record buffer, you can use the 'recall record' to put that record into another group on the same form/report or into another group on another form/report in the same Rally application. The only restrictions are that the new group cannot be read-only and insertions must be allowed.
To copy records from one group to another:
1. Move to the group that contains the record that you want to copy.
2. Place the cursor within that record.
3. Invoke the 'copy record' command. RALLY copies the record to the record buffer.
4. Move the cursor to the group where you want to insert a copy of the record.
5. Invoke the 'recall record' command. Rally copies the record stored in the record buffer to the new group.

Delete Record
Predefined Keys:

Deletes the current record from the current form/report. You can use the 'delete record' command when the cursor is in a form/report group that lets you delete records. You can also use this command with the commands for undeleting records if you want to insert, copy, and move records.
The current record is the one the cursor is on when you invoke this command. The cursor can be on any field in the record.

Predefined Keys:
WPS: KPEnter, F10, GOLD-., GOLD-F, CTRL/Z EDT: KPEnter, F10, GOLD-., GOLD-F, CTRL/Z
Executes a data source query on a form/report. You can use this command only when the form/report is in QUERY mode.
Use the 'set query' command to enter QUERY mode so that you can specify the selection criteria you want. When you issue the 'execute query' command, Rally searches the data source for records that match the criteria specified. Rally displays all the records that meet the query conditions.
You can use the 'set update' command to leave QUERY mode.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Set Query
Predefined Keys:
WPS: FIND, GOLD-, EDT: FIND, PF3, GOLD-,
Switches your Rally session to QUERY mode so that you can specify selection criteria for a data source search. You use the 'execute query' command to perform the search. You can use the 'set query' command only if the form/report allows QUERY mode.
After you issue the 'set query' command, specify the selection criteria immediately, or invoke the 'extend query' command for more complex querying. After you set selection criteria and issue the 'execute query' command, Rally searches the data source for records that match the qualifications you specified. Rally displays all the records that meet the query conditions.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Extend Query
Predefined Keys:
WPS: FIND, GOLD-, EDT: FIND, GOLD-,
Allows advanced query options so that you can query the data source for records based on selection criteria other than the exact match required when you use 'set query'. You must use the 'set query' command before you can use the 'extend query' command. You can use the 'set query' command only if the form/report allows QUERY mode.
The 'extend query' command can be used only on data stored in Oracle Rdb or Oracle7 databases or data accessed using the Open Data Interface.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Rollback
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Removes all changes (updates, deletions, and insertions) made to records in the current transaction. Unless the "commit on leaving record" is turned off (it is on by default), deletions are committed immediately and cannot be rolled back.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Recall Field_value
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Copies the contents of the field buffer to a form/report field. You must position the cursor on the field where you want to enter the value in the field buffer. The value copied to the current field replaces any value in that field.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Copy Field_value
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Copies the value of a form/report field to the field buffer. Before issuing this command, you must position the cursor somewhere in the field whose value you want to copy.
The field value you copy with the 'copy field_value' command can be a number, date, or character string. This value will remain in the field buffer until you leave the application or copy another value to the field buffer.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
List_of_values
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-SELECT, GOLD-KP., GOLD-L EDT: GOLD-SELECT, GOLD-KP., GOLD-L
Moves the cursor to the list of values that applies to the current field of a form/report. You can use this command only when the cursor is in a field that has a list of values associated with it.
A list of values contains values that you can enter for a particular field. Application definers create the lists of values. Not every field has an associated list of values. If a list of values exists for the current field, you can use the 'select value' command to copy one of the values to the current field.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

Predefined Keys:
WPS: SELECT, F10, KPEnter, KP., GOLD-F, CTRL/Z EDT: SELECT, F10, KPEnter, KP., GOLD-F, CTRL/Z
Copies a value from the list of values to the current field of a form/report. You can use this command only when the cursor is on a field of a list of values that is associated with the current form/report field.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

WPS: GOLD-KP5 EDT: GOLD-KP5

Command: write report report.txt
If you do not name a file, Rally prompts you for a name. For example:
Command: write report Filename: report.txt

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Writes a copy of the current page of a form/report to a file. For example, the following command writes a copy of the current page to myfile.txt:

If you do not name a file, Rally prompts you for a name. For example:
Command: write page Filename: myfile.txt
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

Command: write rest_of_report Filename: report.txt
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Go_to Mark
Predefined Keys:

Moves the cursor to a mark that you set previously. Use the 'set mark' command to set the mark. If you have no mark in your file, the 'go_to mark' command has no effect.

You must set a mark before issuing these commands:

o 'copy text'
o 'delete rectangle'
o 'delete text'
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Next Screen

Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Find
Predefined Keys (Contexts other than form/report or query contexts):
WPS: FIND, GOLD-/ EDT: FIND, GOLD-/, PF3
Predefined Keys (Form/report or query contexts):
WPS: GOLD-/ EDT: GOLD-/
Finds a specified character string located between the current cursor position and either the end or the beginning of the text.
When you invoke the 'find' command, Rally prompts you to enter the character string that you want to locate. After typing the string, press either the down arrow or the up arrow to set the direction of the search.
The character string can consist of up to 255 characters. Unless case sensitivity is set, Rally does not differentiate between uppercase and lowercase letters when it searches for the character string.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Go_to Home
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Moves the cursor to the top left corner of the screen or window.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Go_to Top
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-PREV SCREEN, GOLD-up arrow, GOLD-T, GOLD-KP1 EDT: GOLD-PREV SCREEN, GOLD-up arrow, GOLD-T, GOLD-KP5
Moves cursor to the top of the text or, in form/reports, to the first character of a field. The 'go_to top' command has no effect if the cursor is already at the top of the text or at the beginning of the current field.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

Predefined Keys:
WPS: PREV SCREEN, GOLD-P, KP1-PF2 EDT: PREV SCREEN, GOLD-P, KP5-KP7, KP5-KP8
Moves the display to the previous screen or previous screen area. The screen area is determined by the size of the task window and the scroll percent setting, as set in the key definition file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Split_line
Predefined Keys:
WPS: RETURN EDT: RETURN
Inserts a line terminator (carriage return/line-feed) into the text to the left of the cursor. Moves the cursor to the beginning of the new line.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Interrupt
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-I EDT: GOLD-I
On OpenVMS systems, the 'interrupt' command returns you to the environment from which you entered Rally, without affecting your Rally application.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Insert Character_code
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Enters a character using its octal code value; enables you to enter any DEC Multinational Character Set character by typing its equivalent octal value.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Insert Line
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: GOLD-KP0
Inserts a blank line between the current line and the line below. The 'insert line' command moves the cursor to the beginning of the new line. This command has no effect on the current line.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Read Text_file
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-G EDT: GOLD-G
Copies an external file to the current cursor location. Rally inserts the text before the current cursor position.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Paste Text
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-INSERT HERE, GOLD-KP, EDT: GOLD-INSERT HERE, GOLD-KP9
Copies the contents of the paste buffer to the left of the current cursor position. Use the 'copy text', 'delete find', or 'delete text' commands to put text into the paste buffer.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Paste Rectangle
Predefined Keys:
WPS: INSERT HERE, KP,, EDT: INSERT HERE, GOLD-KP6
Copies the contents of the rectangle buffer to the current cursor position.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Recall Line
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-KP9 EDT: GOLD-PF4
Inserts a copy of the contents of the line buffer into your text. You can use this command to move a line from one location to another or to duplicate lines in several places.
To use the 'recall line' command, first use the 'delete line' command to place a text line in the line buffer, then move the cursor to the position where you want that line to appear and invoke the 'recall line' command.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Recall Word
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-PF3, GOLD-LINEFEED, GOLD-F13 EDT: GOLD-KP-, GOLD-LINEFEED, GOLD-F13
Inserts a copy of the contents of the word buffer into your text. You can use this command to move a word from one location to another or to duplicate words in several places.
Use the following procedure to move a word:
1. Move the cursor to the first letter of the word you want to move.
2. Issue the 'delete word ' command.
3. Move the cursor to the position where you want the word to appear.
4. Issue the 'recall word' command.
Similarly, you can copy a word to additional locations by deleting the word, issuing the 'recall word ' command to copy the word back into your text, moving the cursor to the new location, then issuing the 'recall word command at the new cursor location.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Write Text_file
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-W EDT: GOLD-W
Writes the contents of the paste buffer to a file. For example, the following command writes the contents of the paste buffer to report.txt:
Command: write text_file report.txt
If you do not name a file, Rally prompts you for a name. For example:
Command: write text_file Filename: myfile.txt
If there is another file with the same name, Rally creates a new file with that same name. On OpenVMS systems, the new file has a higher version number than the existing file. On MS-DOS and Digital UNIX systems, the new file overwrites the existing file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Previous_character
Predefined Keys:
WPS: DELETE EDT: DELETE
Deletes the character to the left of the cursor.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete To_beginning_of_line
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-DELETE, GOLD-PF3, CTRL/U EDT: GOLD-DELETE, GOLD-PF3, CTRL/U
Deletes all characters from the current cursor position to the beginning of the line.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete To_end_of_line

Local_function
Predefined Keys (except within the Definition System Screen Editor):
WPS: SELECT, KP. EDT: SELECT, KP.
Allows you to invoke a Rally action or task that has been specifically designed for the current form/report. Definers have the option of providing a local function for each form/report they design. If no local function has been defined for the current form/report, this command has no effect.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Copy Text
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Puts a copy of a selected piece of text into the paste buffer. Use the 'set mark' command to specify the text you want to copy. The text you select remains in its current location.
The 'paste text' command copies the text in the paste buffer to the current cursor location. You can copy the same text as many times as required. The contents of the paste buffer change only when you issue another 'copy text', 'delete find', or 'delete text' command. The 'write text_file' command copies the paste buffer contents to a file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Line
Predefined Keys:
WPS: KP9 EDT: PF4
Deletes the current line and puts a copy in the line buffer. The entire line is deleted regardless of where the cursor is on that line. Any lines below the deleted line move up.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Text
Predefined Keys:
WPS: REMOVE, KP-, GOLD-REMOVE, GOLD-KP- EDT: KP9, KP6, REMOVE,GOLD-REMOVE
Moves text from the current location to the paste buffer. Use the 'set mark' command to specify the text you want to move.
Use the 'paste text' command to place text from the paste buffer to the current cursor location. You can copy the same text as many times as required. The contents of the paste buffer change only when you issue a 'copy text', 'delete find', or 'delete text' command. Use the 'write text_file' command to copy the paste buffer contents to an OpenVMS file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Word
Predefined Keys:
WPS: PF3 EDT: KP-
Deletes all the characters from the current cursor position to the end of the word and places a copy in the word buffer. A word is a string of characters composed of letters, digits, underscores, dollar signs, and/or trailing spaces. Words are separated by line terminators and other special characters. When you delete a word or part of a word, the text to the right of the deletion moves toward the left margin.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Find
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Finds the specified character string and deletes everything from the initial cursor position to that string. The deleted text is placed in the paste buffer. Use the 'paste text' command to copy the deleted text to the current cursor location. Use the 'write text_file' command to copy the paste buffer contents to an OpenVMS file. The contents of the paste buffer change only when you issue a 'copy text', 'delete find', or 'delete text' command.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Rectangle
Predefined Keys:
WPS: REMOVE, KP- EDT: REMOVE, KP6
Deletes the contents of a marked rectangular area of the screen and puts a copy in the rectangle buffer. The contents of the rectangle buffer change only when you issue another 'delete rectangle' command or exit from the current application.
After you have deleted a rectangle, you can use the 'paste rectangle' command to replace the rectangle at the current cursor location.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Delete Previous Word
Predefined Keys:
WPS: LINEFEED, F13 EDT: LINEFEED, F13
Deletes all the characters from the current cursor position to the beginning of the word and places a copy in the word buffer. A word is a string of characters composed of letters, digits, underscores, dollar signs, and/or trailing spaces. Words are separated by line terminators and other special characters. When you delete a word or part of a word, the text to the right of the deletion moves toward the left margin.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Global_replace
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-' EDT: GOLD-'
Finds all occurrences of a string and replaces it with another string.
When you invoke the 'global_replace' command, Rally prompts you to enter the search string and the replacement string.
The search and replace character strings can each consist of up to 255 characters. Unless case sensitivity is set, Rally does not differentiate between uppercase and lowercase letters when it searches for the character string.
When the substitution is complete, the cursor is located on the last substitution that was made.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Replace
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-FIND, GOLD-; EDT: GOLD-FIND, GOLD-;, GOLD-PF3
Finds a string and replaces it with another string.
When you invoke the 'replace' command, Rally prompts you to enter the search string and the replacement string. After entering these strings, press either the down arrow or Up Arrow key to set the direction of the search.
The search and replace character strings can each consist of up to 255 characters. Unless case sensitivity is set, Rally does not differentiate between uppercase and lowercase letters when it searches for the character string.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Turns on case sensitivity, regardless of the previous setting.

Set Word_wrap
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Turns on word-wrap mode, regardless of the previous setting.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Clear Case_sensitive
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Turns off case sensitivity, regardless of the previous setting. Use the set case_sensitive command to turn on case sensitivity. The toggle case_sensitive command changes the current case sensitivity setting.
By default, case sensitivity is off when you start a Rally session, as determined by the key definition file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Clear Auto_fill
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Turns off automatic fill mode, regardless of the previous setting. Use the 'set auto_fill' command to turn on automatic fill mode. The 'toggle auto_fill' command changes the current automatic fill mode setting.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Clear Overstrike
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None Turns off overstrike mode, regardless of the previous setting. Use the 'set overstrike' command to turn on overstrike mode. The 'toggle overstrike' command changes the current overstrike setting.
When you start a Rally session, the state of overstrike mode (on or off) is determined by the key definition file. The EDT- and WPS-style key definition files supplied with Rally turn on overstrike mode.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Clear Word_wrap
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Turns off word-wrap mode, regardless of the previous setting. Use the 'set word_wrap' command to turn on word-wrap mode. The 'toggle word_wrap' command changes the current word-wrap mode setting.
By default, word wrap is off when you start a Rally session, as determined by the key definition file.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Finish Turtle
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Indicates that you have finished using turtle mode and want to continue designing the form/report with commands that are not part of turtle mode.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Highlight To_mark
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Applies highlighting to or deletes highlighting from an area of the menu or form/report image you are designing with the Definition System. Before you start to highlight an area, use the 'set highlight_type' command to select a highlight type.
You can also use the 'highlight to_mark' command to remove highlighting.
Use the 'set mark' command to designate the starting point for highlighting.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Highlight Turtle
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Applies highlighting one character location at a time to the menu or form/report you are designing from the Definition System. Before you start to highlight an area, use the 'set highlight_ type' command to select a highlight type.
You can use the 'highlight turtle' command to remove highlighting.
Invoking the 'highlight turtle' command puts your Rally session in turtle mode.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Set Highlight_type
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Enables you to select a highlight type for use in designing menus and form/reports through the Definition System.
Use the 'set highlight_type' command to select a highlight type before using the 'highlight to_mark' or 'highlight turtle' command.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H

Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Removes line-drawing characters from the menu or form/report you are designing with the Definition System. Use the 'set mark' command to designate the start of the line or line portion you want to erase.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Undraw_line Turtle
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Removes one line-drawing character at a time from the image of a menu or form/report you are designing from the Definition System. You move the cursor to determine which line-drawing characters will be removed. Rally replaces the line-drawing characters with spaces. You must delete the spaces if you do not want them in your menu or form/report.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None

Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Mark Window
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Sets the boundaries for the display window in which a task runs. After you mark two diagonally opposite corners of the window, boundary lines appear on the screen. After the window boundaries are set, the cursor appears within the newly defined window.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Grow Window
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Enlarges the size of the current task's display window one line or column at a time. Use the arrow keys to move the boundary lines.
When you finish using the arrow keys to move the lines, press the KPEnter key to terminate the 'grow window' command. The maximum window size is determined by the size of your screen. However, a window can overlap or cover windows of other inactive tasks.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Scroll Window
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Scrolls whatever appears within a task window. You can scroll either from side to side (horizontally) or up and down (vertically). You use the 'scroll window' command to look at a report that has more lines than your window can accommodate or is wider than your task window.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Define Macro
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-{, GOLD-} EDT: GOLD-{, GOLD-}
Initiates the process of defining a macro. The 'define macro' command cannot be invoked from the Command: prompt. To invoke this command, you must use one of the key sequences associated with this command.
You can define macros any time during your Rally session. You can store up to 30 macros at a time in the Rally macro buffer. Macros are numbered from 0 to 29. You can save macros to use in later Rally sessions.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Macro Number
Predefined Keys:
WPS: GOLD-U, F17 (macro number 1), F18 (macro number 2), F19 (macro number 3), F20 (macro number 4), GOLD-F17 (macro number 5), GOLD-F18 (macro number 6), GOLD-F19 (macro number 7), GOLD-F20 (macro number 8) EDT: GOLD-U, F17 (macro number 1), F18 (macro number 2), F19 (macro number 3), F20 (macro number 4), GOLD-F17 (macro number 5), GOLD-F18 (macro number 6), GOLD-F19 (macro number 7), GOLD-F20 (macro number 8)
Selects a specified macro and executes it. The macro must already be defined and located in the macro buffer before you can invoke the 'macro number' command. The 'macro number' command generates an error if the macro you specify has not been defined.
Whenever a macro is defined, it is assigned a number. You specify a macro number on the command line when you invoke the 'macro number' command. For example:
Command: macro number 1
When you invoke the 'macro number' command and then press KPEnter, Rally prompts you for the macro number. Enter the macro number, then press KPEnter. For example:
Command: macro number Type the number of the macro you want to use: 2
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Macro Name
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Executes a macro that is stored in an external file. When you use the 'macro name' command, Rally executes the macro without copying it to your macro buffer. Enter the command and the macro file name on the command line. If you do not enter a file name, RALLY prompts you for one.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Key Defs=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN More Help=GOLD-H
Read Macros
Predefined Keys:
WPS: None EDT: None
Loads the macro buffer with a group of macros that has been stored in a file by the 'write macros' command. When you read in the macros from the file, they retain the same numbers that were assigned to them at the time you issued the 'write macros' command. Once the macros are loaded in the macro buffer, you can invoke the 'macro number' command to perform the individual macros.
Press GOLD-H for more information about this command.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Invoking Rally Commands
To invoke a Rally command:
1. Press GOLD-KP7 or the DO key.
2. Type the name of the command on the command line. You need only type enough of each word to make it unique. For example, you can invoke the command 'write text_file' by typing "wri tex". Press RETURN.
If a command is assigned to a key, you can also invoke the command by pressing the assigned key. To see a list of the keys, choose Help on keys from the main command help menu.
Rally comes with two sets of key definitions: a WPSPLUS-style set and an EDT-style set. The WPSPLUS-style set of definitions is the default. To use the EDT-style keys, define the logical name RALLY$KEY_DEF to RALLY$EDT, as in the following example:
$ DEFINE RALLY$KEY_DEF RALLY$EDT
To return to WPSPLUS-style keys, redefine RALLY$KEY_DEF:
$ DEFINE RALLY$KEY_DEF RALLY$WPS
It is also possible to create your own key definition file.
Help on Commands
Help is available on each Rally command. To receive help on a command:
1. Press GOLD-KP7 or the DO key.
2. Press GOLD-H.
3. Follow the menu path to the help message for the command.
If a command is associated with a key in the WPS-style or EDT- style key definition file, that key is listed at the front of the help message on that command. Keys available from both VT100- style and VT200-style keyboards are listed first; keys only available on VT200-style keyboards are listed after them.
To leave help, press RETURN or use the 'quit action' command.
[end]

The command you supply to be repeated must be defined as a key (or key sequence) in the key definition file. You cannot type the command you want to repeat on the Command: prompt line.
To use the 'repeat' command:
1. Enter the 'repeat' command and press KPEnter. Rally displays the Repeat count: prompt.
2. Enter the repeat number and press KPEnter. (The repeat number can range from 1 through 9999.) Rally returns the cursor to its previous location in the text or on the form/report.
3. Press the key for the command or character you want to repeat. RALLY performs the operation as many times as you specified.
Alias: setrptcnt
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
When you invoke the 'finish action' command from a menu, the result depends on whether or not you have already selected a choice. If you have not selected a choice, 'finish action' causes Rally to exit from the menu. If you have selected a choice, 'finish action' processes that choice.
The 'finish action' command performs a data source commit by default. However, in designing a Rally application, a definer can specify in form/report packets that the 'finish application', 'finish action, and 'finish task' commands do not perform a commit. For more information about data source commits, see the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual.
Alias: exitaction
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B

However, in designing a Rally application, a definer can specify in form/report packets that the 'finish application', 'finish action, and 'finish task' commands do not perform a commit. For more information about data source commits, see the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual.
Alias: exitappl
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If you have several task windows on your screen and you issue the 'finish task' command to end one of them, that window disappears from the screen.
The 'finish task' command performs a data source commit by default. However, in designing a Rally application, a definer can specify in form/report packets that the 'finish application', 'finish action, and 'finish task' commands do not perform a commit. For more information about data source commits, see the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual.
Alias: exittask
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'quit action' command is useful in ending an action where you were only looking at information, not adding to or changing it.
The 'quit action' command does not override any commits that you performed during a session. The command negates only those changes made since the most recent commit.
Note that Rally automatically commits certain changes to the data source at particular times during your Rally session. Thus, when you use the 'quit action' command, Rally might not be able to restore the data source to the state it was in when you began your session. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for more detail.
In some instances, you will not be able to enter the 'quit action' command on the command line. Press one of the predefined keys when you are in one of these situations.
Alias: abortaction
[end]

The 'quit application' command is useful in ending a Rally session where you were only looking at information, not adding to or changing it.
The 'quit application' command does not override any commits that you performed during a session. The command negates only those changes made since the most recent commit.
Note that Rally automatically commits certain changes to the data source at particular times during your Rally session. Thus, when you use the 'quit application' command, Rally might not be able to restore the data source to the state it was in when you began your session. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for more detail.
Alias: abortappl
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B

The 'quit task' command does not override any commits that you performed during a session. The command negates only those changes made since the most recent commit.
Note that Rally automatically commits certain changes to the data source at particular times during your Rally session. Thus, when you use the 'quit task' command, Rally might not be able to restore the data source to the state it was in when you began your session. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for more detail.
Alias: aborttask
[end]

To use the 'select task' command, you must have at least two active tasks.
The current task is displayed in the window where the cursor is positioned.
If you position the cursor outside of any defined window, Rally gives you an error message. You can press the KPEnter key to turn off the error message. Then, move the cursor to a position inside a window.
If there is only one window on the screen, 'select task' works as described, but the only task you can activate is the one displayed.
Alias: picktask
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Application commands are created by application definers and used by end users. Application definers assign a number from 1 to 25 for each application command they define. If you create application commands for your applications, you should provide the application end users with the application command numbers and function.
To use an application command, an end user can use either of the following methods:
o Enter the 'application_command' command and application command number at the Command: prompt.
Command: application_command 7
o Invoke the key sequence associated with the 'application_ command', then enter the application command number at the prompt:
Type the number of the application command you want to use: 7
Alias:
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If there are two or more windows on the screen, the 'next task' command moves the cursor from one window to the next. If each task uses the full screen, the 'next task' command brings the next active task to the screen.
Continue using the 'next task' command until you reach the task you want.
Alias: toggletask
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
You use the arrow keys to move the boundary lines. After moving the lines, press the KPEnter key to terminate the 'shrink window' command.
The smallest Rally window holds only a single character.
To decrease the size of a Rally window:
1. Invoke the 'shrink window' command.
2. Press an arrow key to move the boundary line toward the center of the window. To move the top boundary line, press the up arrow key. The Left Arrow key moves the left boundary, the right arrow key moves the right boundary, and the down arrow key moves the bottom boundary.
3. Repeat the previous step until the window is the size that you want it. Each time you press the down arrow or up arrow key, the window boundary moves one line toward the center. When you press the left arrow or Right Arrow key, the window boundary moves one column toward the center.
4. Press the KPEnter key when you have finished moving the boundary lines to set the window size at its current dimensions.
While you are shrinking the window, the text remains stationary. As the window size decreases, some text might be covered up as the boundary lines close in. After you press KPEnter to establish the new window size, Rally scrolls the window to place the current cursor position in the visible portion.
After the window is resized, Rally may reformat a form/report to display fewer records per page.
Alias: compresswdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
On OpenVMS systems, printer output from Rally goes to the print queue SYS$PRINT. You can send printer output to a different print queue through logical assignment from the DCL level or within an ADL procedure.
On MS-DOS systems, printer output from Rally goes to LPT1. You can send printer output to a different print device by setting the RALLY_PRINTER environment variable from the MS-DOS prompt or within an ADL procedure.
On Digital UNIX systems, printer output from Rally goes to the default printer. You can send printer output to a different print device by setting the RALLY_PRINTER environment variable from the Digital UNIX prompt or within an ADL procedure.
Contrast this command with the 'write screen' command, which sends output to a file.
Alias: ALIASprint_screen
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'write screen' command converts line drawings to dashes, bars, and plus signs.
On OpenVMS and Digital UNIX systems, by default, all highlighting characters are included in the file. If you use the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier, the 'write screen' command ignores highlighting. For example:
Command: write screen myfile.txt /nohighlighting
On MS-DOS systems, highlighting characters are not included in the file; the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier has no effect.
Contrast this command with the 'print screen' command, which sends output to a printer.
Alias: wscreen
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you use the 'debug current' command, Rally lets you specify whether or not to enable tracing and (if you enable tracing) the name of the output file to contain the trace information.
Alias: debug_current
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you use the 'edit current' command, Rally lets you edit the current application object.
The dynamic editing (GOLD-DO) capability, previously (before Version 7.0) limited to use while running an application from within the Rally Definition System, is now also available anywhere in the Rally Definition System. The use of dynamic editing from a Definition System form or menu is referred to as "parallel editing" in certain Rally messages. That is, when you press GOLD-DO in any form or menu of the Definition System, you are performing parallel editing.
When you perform parallel editing, Rally displays the Edit Application menu. This contrasts with what happens when you press GOLD-DO from within the running application: namely, Rally displays the Definition System menu for editing the current object.
Parallel editing gives you flexibility during application development and debugging. For example, consider the following scenario. While running an application, you press GOLD-DO in a menu. While editing the menu choices, you press GOLD-DO and edit a form/report packet called by a menu choice. You then return to the menu editor, and then to the running application: you see the effects of any changes you made to both the menu and the form/report packet.
If you are performing parallel editing, you cannot use GOLD-DO: Rally displays an error message indicating that parallel editing is not allowed while parallel editing is in progress.
Alias: edit_current
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you use the 'stack' command, Rally displays the application action stack.
To dismiss this display and return to the application, use 'quit action' (GOLD-Q).
To delete an object from the action stack, use 'delete record'. If you delete the top-most item from the stack, execution continues at the next item down (the new top-most item) after you dismiss the action stack display.
If a form/report or ADL procedure is on the stack, you can use 'local function' to display the form/report groups and fields or ADL variables. You can change the values of form/report fields or ADL variables by moving the cursor to them and typing in new values.
NOTE
If you change the value of a form/report field or an ADL variable, you might change the subsequent behavior and flow of the application, depending on the application's design.
This feature is intended to help developers in debugging applications. For detailed information on the action stack and how Rally uses it at runtime, see the Concepts chapter in the Developing Oracle Rally Applications manual.
Alias: stack
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B

The cursor must be located on the menu response area when you invoke this command.

Definers can set up menus so that users can make choices by pressing keys that correspond to the items on the menu. The key that chooses the first item in the menu is referred to as function key 1 in the key definition file. In the key definition file, a definer can assign any key to be function key 1, function key 2, and so on. The WPS and EDT key definitions files that are provided with Rally contain no such definitions.
For example, if a menu choice was defined to be a function key menu, users can enter function_key_choice 1 at the Command: prompt when they want to choose the first item in a menu. For example:
Command: function_key_choice 1
Note that function key menus cannot be used effectively unless the definer modifies the key definitions.
Alias: menu
[end]

You can perform the 'recall query' command either from query mode or from other modes if the form/report allows querying. If the form/report is not in query mode, then the 'recall query' command first puts the form/report into query mode. In any case, the 'recall query' command restores the query values and extended query expressions for all fields to their state as of the most recent successful query.
See the 'extend query' command for more information about queries.
Alias: recallquery
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'undelete record after' command does not undo the effects of prior deletions, nor does it save or restore the values of computed or aggregate fields; these values are recomputed when the other field values are recalled. When performed in a child group, the 'undelete record after' command does not save or restore the values of child key fields; rather, child key fields are filled in to match the corresponding parent key fields from the parent record under which the new record is created.
Alias: undelrecafter
[end]

When performed in a child group, the 'undelete record before' command does not save or restore the values of child key fields; rather, child key fields are filled in to match the corresponding parent key fields from the parent record under which the new record is created.
Alias: undelrecbefore
[end]

You cannot use this command if the cursor is in the lowest, or last, group of a form/report.

An application developer can specify the behavior of the record navigation commands ('first record', 'last record', 'next record', and 'previous record'). Record navigation behavior is a form/report packet attribute. The keywords for selecting the record navigation behavior are:
o INSTANCE: Record navigation is restricted to the current instance of the current group.
o GROUP: Allows record navigation across instances of the current group, but is restricted to records in this data group.
o FORM/REPORT: Record navigation proceeds down (and up) across all group boundaries until it reaches the last record in the last group.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: rlast
[end]

o INSTANCE: Record navigation is restricted to the current instance of the current group.

o INSTANCE: Record navigation is restricted to the current instance of the current group.

The 'first scroll_area' command performs the same function as the 'first record' command.
For a scrolling group of records, the scroll area consists of the number of records that can be displayed on the screen or window at one time.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: prhome
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'last record' command positions the cursor on the last record in the form/report group. The 'last scroll_area' command places the cursor on the first record of the last scroll area of the group.
For a group of records that scrolls, the scroll area consists of the number of records that can be displayed on the screen or window at one time. For example, if the screen can accommodate 20 records at a time and there are 65 records in the group, there will be four scroll areas, with the last area having only five records. If the cursor is on one of the first 20 records when you issue the 'last scroll_area' command, the screen will clear and then display records 61 through 65, with the cursor on the first field of record 61.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: prlast
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
For a group of records that scrolls, the scroll area consists of the number of records that can be displayed on the screen or window at one time. For example, if the screen can accommodate 20 records at a time and there are 65 records in the group, there will be four scroll areas, with the last area having only five records. If the cursor is on one of the first 20 records when you issue the 'next scroll_area' command, records 21 through 40 will overwrite the first set with the cursor on the first field of record 21.
Use this command to move the cursor in lists of values.
Alias: prnext
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
For a group of records that scrolls, the scroll area consists of the number of records that can be displayed on the screen or window at one time. For example, if the screen can accommodate 20 records at a time and there are 65 records in the group, there will be four scroll areas, with the last area having only five records. If the cursor is in any record between record 41 and record 60 the 41st when you issue the 'previous scroll_area' command, records 21 through 40 will overwrite 41 through 60 and the cursor will be on the first field of record 21.
Use this command to move the cursor in lists of values.
Alias: prprev
[end]

You can use this command in a child of the main group (such as G1) to visit a field in the main group. You cannot use this command to visit a format group or a list of values group.

If you have not previously entered that group, Rally positions the cursor on the first record of the group. Otherwise, Rally positions the cursor on the record where you were before you exited from that group.

If you have not previously entered that group, Rally positions the cursor on the first record of the group. Otherwise, Rally positions the cursor on the record where you were before you exited from that group.

[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
You can only use the 'previous group' command when the cursor is in a form/report group other than the first (or highest) group.
You can use this command in a child of the main group (such as G1) to visit a field in the main group. You cannot use this command to visit a format group or a list of values group.
NOTE
You can use the 'previous group' command to move from a list of values back to its associated form/report field without selecting a value.

After you delete the record, the cursor moves to the first field of the next record in the current record group. Records that appear after the deleted record move up to occupy the space left by the deletion.
If you delete the bottom record in a group, Rally positions the cursor on the previous record in that group, if there is one. If there are no records left in the group, Rally places the cursor in the next higher parent group. If you have deleted the last record in the topmost group of a form/report, Rally positions the cursor in the top left-hand corner of the form/report.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: delrec

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If you are not currently in a group but are starting from an empty page, the cursor is in the upper left corner above the first group. By issuing the 'insert record after' command in this situation, you create the first record for the first group. In this case, the command also displays the field labels.
After you issue the 'insert record after' command, enter data in the new record fields. You can use this command only when the cursor is in a form/report group that allows insertion of records.
If you return to the same form/report once the new record is committed to the data source, the record location in the current group might change, depending on the sort system that has been defined for that group.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: insafter
[end]

By issuing the 'insert record before' command in this situation, you create the first record for the first group. In this case, the command also displays the field labels.
After you issue the 'insert record before' command, enter data in the new record fields. You can use this command only when the cursor is in a form/report that allows insertion of records.
If you return to the form/report once the new record is committed to the data source, the record location in the current group might change, depending on the sort system that has been defined for that group.

Alias: insbefore

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If you are not currently in a group but are starting from an empty page, the cursor is in the upper left corner above the first group. By issuing the 'insert record next_group' command in this situation, you create the first record for the first group. You can also do this with the 'insert record after' and 'insert record before' commands.
You can also use the 'insert record next_group' command when there are already child records present in the next group. In this case, if you have not previously entered the child group, Rally opens a blank line at the top of the next group and places the cursor on that line so you can insert a new record. If you have previously entered and left the child group, Rally opens a blank line above the record where you were before you exited from the child group.
When you invoke the 'insert record next_group' command from an existing record, the cursor can be located on any field in that record.
If you return to the same form/report once the new record is committed to the data source, its location in the current group might change, depending on the sort system that has been defined for that group. You can use the 'insert record after' command to insert the next record in this child group.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: finsnext
[end]
