Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If your 'commit' command is successful, RALLY issues no message. You see no change in the screen unless an error occurs. If an error does occur, the record causing the error is displayed on the screen along with the error message. The cursor is positioned on the problem record, but not necessarily on the problem field.
The default for the 'finish application', 'finish action', and 'finish task' commands is to perform a commit. However, in designing a Rally application, a definer can specify in form/report packets that these commands not perform a commit. For more information about data source commits, see the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual.
Alias: commit
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
In general, if you make any changes to the data source before you enter QUERY mode, Rally commits those changes when it shifts into QUERY mode. However, some Rally applications are designed so that such changes are rolled back. See the the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for more information about commits and rollbacks.
To query the data source:
1. Issue the 'set query' command to enter QUERY mode.
2. For simple querying, enter the selection criteria and press KPEnter. You must enter the value as you would enter the data in the field. Therefore, if the field has an input format, enter the value using that format. Simple querying searches for values that match exactly the criteria you enter.
3. Issue the 'execute query' command to have Rally display all records that meet the selection criteria.
When you invoke the 'set query' command and follow it immediately with the 'execute query' command (that is, without specifying any selection criteria), Rally displays all the records that the form/report has been defined to show. You can use this method to restore the form/report to its appearance before you issued some 'execute query' commands.
The 'execute query' command is not affected by the current setting for case sensitivity. In Rally, simple queries are always case sensitive. Thus, if you want to locate a record where the name is Smith, you must type the name exactly that way. With a simple query, Rally will not match SMITH or smith with Smith. Extended queries may or may not be case sensitive, depending on the specific query operator.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: query
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'set update' command to leave QUERY mode.
In general, if you make any changes to the data source before you enter QUERY mode, Rally commits those changes when it shifts into QUERY mode. However, some Rally applications are designed so that such changes are rolled back.
To query the data source using the query commands:
1. Issue the 'set query' command to enter QUERY mode.
2. Enter the selection criteria and press KPEnter. You must enter the value as you would enter the data in the field. Therefore, if the field has an input format, enter the value using that format.
3. Issue the 'execute query' command to have Rally display all the records that meet the selection criteria.
When you invoke the 'set query' command and follow it immediately with the 'execute query' command (that is, without specifying any selection criteria), Rally displays all the records that the form/report has been defined to show.
Alias: qbe
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you issue the 'set query' and 'extend query' commands, specify the selection criteria that you want, and issue the 'execute query' command. You must enter the value as you would enter the data in the field. Therefore, if the field has an input format, enter the value using that format. Rally searches the data source for records that match the qualifications you specified. RALLY displays all the records that satisfy the query conditions.
As an alternative to issuing the 'extend query' command and being prompted for the query expression, you can enter the command and the query expression on a single line. For example:
Command: extend query "contains Paper"
You can specify sorting of records returned by the query. At the end or the beginning of the extended query expression, you can include a sort specification in the following format:
SORT {ASCENDING|DESCENDING} [sort-key]
ASCENDING indicates ascending sequence, DESCENDING indicates descending sequence, and sort-key is the sort key number. ASCENDING and DESCENDING can be abbreviated. For example:
contains Paper sort desc 1
This specifies that records containing "Paper" (case-insensitive) are to be returned, and that they are to be sorted in descending sequence with the current field as the primary sort key (1). You could then move to another field and specify another query expression with a second sort key (for example, sort asc 2). The sort key is optional; fields without a sort key are sorted in an indeterminate order after those with a specific sort key.
You can use the 'set update' command to leave QUERY mode.
In general, if you make any changes to the data source before you enter QUERY mode, Rally commits those changes when it shifts into QUERY mode. However, some Rally applications are designed so that such changes are rolled back. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for more information about commits and rollbacks.
To query the data source using 'extend query':
1. Issue the 'set query' command to enter QUERY mode.
2. Move the cursor to the field you wish to query and issue the 'extend query' command.
3. Enter one of the selection criteria listed in the following table, enter a value, and press KPEnter. An asterisk (*) appears in the field for which you have entered extended query selection criteria. Enter the values as you would enter data in the field. Therefore, if the field has an input format, use that format.
Extended Query Operators describes the selection criteria.
Table 1 Extended Query Operators
Case Operator SensitivSelects records in the following way
EQ or = Yes All records with a value in the queried field equal to the query value. NE or Yes All records with a value in the queried field {} not equal to the query value. LT or { Yes All records with a value in the queried field less than the query value. GT or } Yes All records with a value in the queried field greater than the query value. LE or Yes All records with a value in the queried field {= less than or equal to the query value. GE or Yes All records with a value in the queried field }= greater than or equal to the query value. CONTAINS No All records with a character string in the queried field that matches the query character string. Enclose in quotes if you include a character string with a blank in it. Unique abbreviation accepted (C). MATCHES No All records with a complete character string in the queried field that contains the query string. Enclose in quotes if you include a character string with a blank in it. Wildcards allowed: asterisks (*) for any string; percent (%) for any one letter. Unique abbreviation accepted (M). STARTS Yes All records with an initial character string in the queried field that matches the query string. Unique abbreviation accepted (S). AND, OR The user can enter multiple query conditions in a given field by using AND and OR. NOT Negates the operator before which it is placed.
CONTAINS, MATCHES, and STARTS can be abbreviated to as few as a single character each.
Within a field, the extended query can make use of AND, NOT, and OR. Queries in multiple fields are connected by implicit AND statements.
Examples of valid extended queries are:
ST B NOT MA *lamp* CONTAINS Paper sort desc 1
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: extquery
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you have issued the 'commit' command or one of the finish commands, all changes made up to that point are committed and cannot be rolled back. Note that using the 'commit' command is not the only way to commit changes to the data source. Some commits are performed automatically when you invoke certain commands.
If "commit on leaving record" is in effect for the current form/report group, the entire form/report is committed as soon as the cursor moves away from the current record. If "commit on leaving record" is in effect, the 'rollback' command only affects changes that you made since you last moved between records. For more information about data source commits, see the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual.
Alias: rollback
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The field value can be any Rally data type (a number, date, or character string), but the field must have the same data type as the value in the field buffer. If the data type is not the same, Rally issues an error message.
No formatting information is stored in the field buffer.
You can continue to use the 'recall field_value' command to copy the contents of the field buffer into several different fields in your RALLY application. The value in the field buffer remains the same until another 'copy field_value' command is issued.
After you have used the 'copy field_value' command to put a value in the field buffer, you use the 'recall field_value' command to put that value into another field on the same form/report or into another field on another form/report in the same Rally application. The only restriction is that the data type of the new field must be the same as the data type of the original field.
Using both the 'copy field_value' and 'recall field_value' commands, you can copy values from one form/report field to another. The steps are:
1. Move the cursor to the field whose value you want to copy.
2. Invoke the 'copy field_value' command. Rally copies the value to the field buffer.
3. Move the cursor on the field you want to fill with the value stored in the field buffer.
4. Invoke the 'recall field_value' command. Rally copies the value stored in the field buffer to the field on the current form/report.
Alias: putfield
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Formatting information is lost when the value is copied to the field buffer. Only the value is copied. For example, when you use the 'copy field_value' command on fields displaying $1.75 or +1.75, the value stored in the field buffer is identical.
You can also use the 'copy field_value' command to copy data from a read-only field. (The 'delete word ' and 'delete line' commands can only be used to copy data when the field can be modified.)
When you issue the 'copy field_value' command, you see no change on the screen, nor does Rally issue a success message.
After you have used the 'copy field_value' command to put a value in the field buffer, you can use the 'recall field_value' to put that value into another field on the same form/report or into another field on another form/report in the same Rally application. The only restriction is that the data type of the new field must be the same as the data type of the original field.
Using both the 'copy field_value' and 'recall field_value' commands, you can copy values from one form/report to another. The steps are:
1. Move to the form/report that contains the value you want to copy.
2. Place the cursor on the field whose value you want to copy.
3. Invoke the 'copy field_value' command. Rally copies the value to the field buffer.
4. Move the cursor to the field you want to fill with the value stored in the field buffer.
5. Invoke the 'recall field_value' command. Rally copies the value stored in the field buffer to the field on the current form/report. If there is a value in that field, RALLY replaces that value with the one in the field buffer.
Alias: pickfield
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To copy a value to a field:
1. Move the cursor to the field that is associated with the list of values.
2. Invoke the 'list_of_values' command to move the cursor to that list of values.
3. Move the cursor to the value you want to copy.
4. Enter the 'select value' command. Rally copies the current value to the field where the cursor was last located and moves the cursor to the next field. If the cursor was located in the last field of a record, Rally returns the cursor to that field and signals you with a beep from the terminal.
You can use the 'previous group' command to move from a list of values back to its associated form/report field without selecting a value.
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: flistval
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To copy a value to a field:
1. Move the cursor to the field that is associated with the list of values.
2. Invoke the 'list_of_values' command to move the cursor to that list of values.
3. Move the cursor to the value you want to copy, using arrow keys.
4. Now invoke the 'select value' command. Rally copies the current value to the field where the cursor was last located and moves the cursor to the next field.
Alias: fpickval
[end]

On OpenVMS systems, printer output from Rally goes to the print queue SYS$PRINT. You can send printer output to a different print queue through logical assignment from the DCL level or within an ADL procedure.
On MS-DOS systems, printer output from Rally goes to LPT1. You can send printer output to a different print device by setting the RALLY_PRINTER environment variable from the MS-DOS prompt or within an ADL procedure.
On Digital UNIX systems, printer output from Rally goes to the default printer. You can send printer output to a different print device by setting the RALLY_PRINTER environment variable from the Digital UNIX prompt or within an ADL procedure.
Contrast this command with the 'write report' command, which sends output to a file.
Alias: pall
[end]

The 'write report' command converts line drawings to dashes, bars, and plus signs.
On OpenVMS and Digital UNIX systems, by default, all highlighting characters are included in the file. If you use the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier, the 'write report' command ignores highlighting. For example:
Command: write report report.txt /nohighlighting
On MS-DOS systems, highlighting characters are not included in the file; the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier has no effect.
Contrast this command with the 'print report' command, which sends the report to a printer.

If the search initiated by the 'find' command is unsuccessful, no message is displayed.
If you press the down arrow, Rally looks for the string between the current cursor location and the end of the text. If you press the up arrow, RALLY looks for the string between the current cursor location and the beginning of the text.
If the search is unsuccessful, the cursor position is determined by the "find remain" setting in the key definition file. If "find remain" is set, the cursor remains at the position from which the search began. If "find remain" is not set, the cursor goes either to the beginning or the end of the text, depending on what direction you specified with the arrow keys.
You can repeat a search for the same character string by invoking the 'find' command without specifying the string again. Whenever you specify a string, Rally saves it in a buffer. The string remains in that buffer until you issue another 'find' command or a 'delete find', 'replace', or 'global_replace' command that searches for a different string.
To find a specified character string:
1. Invoke the 'find' command. Rally displays the Find string: prompt.
2. Type the character string you want to locate. Do not use quotation marks.
3. Press the appropriate arrow key to set the direction of the search. To search in the forward direction, press the down arrow key. To search in the reverse direction, press the up arrow key.
Alias: find
[end]

If you entered Rally from ALL-IN-1, the 'interrupt' command brings up the ALL-IN-1 interrupt menu.

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
With the 'insert character_code' command, you can enter control characters such as line feeds or form feeds. You can also enter output control characters (such as partial line down and set transmit state), special symbols (such as section sign and copyright sign), and letters with diacritical marks.
On some terminals, such as the VT200-series terminals, the special symbols and letters with diacritical marks appear on the screen in their proper form. On other terminals, these characters might appear as several characters inside angle brackets to approximate the intended graphic. Some control characters are displayed with a caret preceding the characters, for example, ^U for CTRL/U. Others have two or more letters inside angle brackets, for example, {FF} for form feed (CTRL/L). Regardless of how the character is displayed on the screen, only one character is actually stored.
To use the 'insert character_code' command:
1. Move the cursor to the place where you want to insert the special character.
2. Invoke the 'insert character_code' command.
3. When Rally displays the Enter character code in octal: prompt, type the octal code for the character you want to insert.
4. Press KPEnter to have the corresponding character inserted at the current cursor position.
Alias: ctrlchar
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the KPEnter key instead of the 'insert line' command when you want to break the current line at the cursor and put the remaining characters on a new line below.
Alias: insertline
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
When you invoke the 'read text_file' command, you can supply a file name. For example:
Command: read text_file myfile.txt
If you do not supply a file name, Rally prompts you for the name of the file. Enter the file name and then press KPEnter. For example:
Command: read text_file Filename: myfile.txt
The default file type is .TXT
Rally displays an error message if it cannot locate or open the file you specified.
Alias: readfile
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'set mark' command to specify the text you want to copy or move. If the paste buffer is empty when you invoke the 'paste text' command, nothing is copied and no error message appears.
You can use the 'paste text' command to copy the same text as many times as you need. The contents of the paste buffer change only when you issue a 'copy text', 'delete find', or 'delete text' command.
To move text from one place to another:
1. Place the cursor at the beginning of the text you want to move.
2. Issue the 'set mark' command to mark this location.
3. Move the cursor to the end of the text you want to move.
4. Issue the 'delete text' command. Rally deletes the text from its current location and puts it in the paste buffer.
5. Move the cursor to the new location where you want to place the text.
6. Invoke the 'paste text' command. Rally puts a copy of the paste buffer contents to the left of the cursor.
To put a copy of some text in another location, use the 'copy text' command instead of the 'delete text' command in step 4. Rally leaves the selected text in its original location and puts a copy of that text in the paste buffer.
Alias: cpfrombuf
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'paste rectangle' command allows you to copy the contents of the rectangle buffer to another location. The contents of the rectangle buffer overwrites the existing rectangle, beginning at the cursor position.
Use the 'paste rectangle' command to relocate a rectangle that has been removed from its original location with the 'delete rectangle' command. The contents of the rectangle buffer change only when you issue another 'delete rectangle' command or exit from the current application.
To relocate a rectangle:
1. Move the cursor to a corner of the rectangle (usually the upper left-hand corner).
2. Use the 'set mark' command to mark that corner of the rectangle.
3. Move the cursor to the opposite corner of the rectangle that you want to relocate.
4. Invoke the 'delete rectangle' command to remove the rectangle from its current location and place a copy in the rectangle buffer.
5. Move the cursor to the new location where you want to place the rectangle.
6. Use the 'paste rectangle' command to put a copy of the rectangle buffer contents in the new location.
When you use the 'paste rectangle' command, RALLY overlays the rectangle so that whatever was on the screen in that location is lost. The 'paste text' command pushes existing text down so that the old text is not lost.
When you use the 'delete rectangle' command, Rally deletes only the text that lies within the rectangle defined by the mark you set and the current cursor position. Text to the right or left of the rectangle boundary is not deleted. When you use the 'delete text' command, Rally deletes all text starting at the mark, going to the end of each line, and finishing up at the current cursor position. No text remains on the screen between the top of the rectangle and the bottom.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the entire application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Commands in other contexts use the same predefined keys as this command. See the Oracle Rally Command Reference Manual for a discussion of command contexts.
Alias: overlayblk
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'recall line' command has no effect if the line buffer is empty.
When you use the 'recall line' command, Rally inserts the line below the line that the cursor is on.
To copy a line, use the 'delete line' command and then the 'recall line' command before moving the cursor to the new location. After you have restored the line, move the cursor to the new location and issue the 'recall line' command again.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: undelline
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'recall word' command has no effect if the word buffer is empty.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks.)
Alias: undelword
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'copy text' or 'delete text' commands to copy text to the paste buffer. The contents of the paste buffer remain the same after you have issued the 'write text_file' command. If you issue the command when the paste buffer is empty, RALLY displays an error message.
When you finish using the 'write text_file' command, the cursor returns to its previous position in your work.
To write the contents of the paste buffer to a file:
1. Move the cursor to the beginning of the text you want to copy.
2. Issue the 'set mark' command to mark that location.
3. Move the cursor to the end of the text you want to copy.
4. Issue the 'copy text' command. Rally puts a copy of that text in the paste buffer and then displays the File to write: prompt.
5. Enter the name of the file that you want to contain the contents of the paste buffer and press KPEnter.
The 'write text_file' command converts line drawings to dashes, bars, and plus signs. If you use the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier, the 'write text_file' command ignores highlighting. For example:
Command: write text_file myfile.txt /nohighlighting
On MS-DOS and Digital UNIX systems, the /NOHIGHLIGHTING qualifier has no effect.
Alias: writefile
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Any characters to the right of the cursor shift one column to the left when you use the 'delete previous character' command. If the cursor is on the first character of a line when you issue the 'delete previous character' command, Rally deletes the line terminator at the end of the previous line. This command has no effect if the cursor is located on the first character of a field or other text.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: bdelete
[end]

To use the 'copy text' command to copy text from one place to another:
1. Place the cursor at the beginning of text you want to copy.
2. Issue the 'set mark' command to mark this location.
3. Move the cursor to the end of the text you want to copy.
4. Issue the 'copy text' command. Rally puts a copy of that text in the paste buffer.
5. Move the cursor to the new location where you want to place the copy of the text.
6. Invoke the 'paste text' command. Rally puts a copy of the paste buffer contents to the left of the cursor.
To move text from one location to another, use the 'delete text' command with the 'paste text' command.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the entire application (that is, across all actions and tasks).

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After using the 'delete line' command to move a line to the line buffer, you can use the 'recall line' command to place a copy of the line buffer contents in another location. The contents of the line buffer remain the same until you issue another 'delete line' command or exit from the current application.
All characters on the deleted line are stored in the line buffer when you use the 'delete line' command, including any characters that might go beyond the right-hand screen margin.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: delline
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Alias:

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you use the 'delete word ' command to move a word or part of a word to the word buffer, you can use the 'recall word' command to place a copy of the word buffer contents in another location. The contents of the word buffer remain the same until you issue another 'delete word ' command or exit from the current application.
The 'delete word ' command does not delete the line terminator that follows a word at the end of a line.
The 'delete word ' command considers spaces between words as belonging to the previous word. Therefore, if your cursor is on a space, the 'delete word ' command deletes only to the end of the spaces to the right.
All deleted characters are stored in the word buffer when you use the 'delete word ' command, including any characters that might go beyond the right-hand screen margin.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: delword
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'delete find' command is similar to the 'delete text' command. However, when you use 'delete find' make sure that the located string is really the one you want. If you should delete the wrong text, use the 'paste text' command to restore the text before moving the cursor again.
The 'delete find' command erases a mark that might have been set with the 'set mark' command, even if the search is unsuccessful.
If the "find to end" setting is in effect, the specified string is also deleted along with the rest of the text. By default, the "find to end" setting is not in effect.
To use the 'delete find' command:
1. Invoke the 'delete find' command.
2. When Rally displays the Find string: prompt, enter the string you want to use to mark the end of the text to be deleted.
3. Press either the Down or up arrow key to determine the direction of the search.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the entire application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: findanddel
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
You can use the 'delete rectangle' and 'paste rectangle' commands to move fields and labels in form/report screen editing.
To relocate a rectangle:
1. Move the cursor to a corner of the rectangle (usually the upper left-hand corner).
2. Use the 'set mark' command to mark that corner.
3. Move the cursor to the opposite corner of the rectangle that you want to relocate.
4. Invoke the 'delete rectangle' command to remove the rectangle from its current location and place a copy in the rectangle buffer.
5. Move the cursor to the new location where you want to relocate the rectangle.
6. Use the 'paste rectangle' command to put a copy of the rectangle buffer contents at the new location. The new text overlays the existing text on the screen; it is not inserted into the existing text.
When you use the 'delete rectangle' command, RALLY deletes only the text that lies within the rectangle defined by the mark you set and the current cursor position. Text to the right or left of the rectangle boundary is not deleted or moved. In contrast, when you use the 'delete text' command, Rally deletes all text starting at the mark, going to the end of each line, and finishing up at the current cursor position. No text remains on the screen between the top of the rectangle and the bottom.
When you use the 'paste rectangle' command, Rally overlays the rectangle so that whatever was on the screen in that location is lost. In contrast, the 'paste text' command pushes existing text down so that the old text is not lost.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the entire application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: removeblk
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you use the 'delete previous word' command to move a word or part of a word to the word buffer, you can use the 'recall word' command to place a copy of the word buffer contents in another location. The contents of the word buffer remain the same until you issue another 'delete previous word' command or exit from the current application.
If the cursor is at the beginning of a line, the 'delete previous word' command deletes the line terminator at the end of the previous line.
The 'delete previous word' command considers spaces between words as belonging to the previous word. Therefore, if your cursor is in white space, the 'delete previous word' command deletes the space to the left and the word before that space. However, if the area between the cursor and the beginning of the line consists only of spaces, the 'delete previous word' command deletes only those spaces, not the word or space at the end of the previous line.
The paste, rectangle, line, and word buffers are shared throughout the application (that is, across all actions and tasks).
Alias: pwdelete ]
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To perform string replacements:
1. Issue the 'global_replace' command. Rally displays the Find string: prompt.
2. Type the string you want Rally to search for.
3. Press the KPEnter key to indicate that you have finished entering the string. Rally now displays the Replace string: prompt.
4. Enter the string with which you want to replace the search string.
5. Press the KPEnter key to indicate that you have finished entering the replacement string.
Note that if you want to perform a single substitution, you can use the 'replace' command instead of the 'global_replace' command.
Alias: glblreplace
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If the 'replace' command is successful, Rally positions the cursor to the right of the replacement string. If the existing string cannot be found, the cursor either remains in its original position or moves to the end of the page, depending on whether or not "find remain" is set.
You can use the 'repeat' command to have Rally perform several searches and replacements of the same strings. Invoke the 'repeat' command and enter the number of replacements in response to the Repeat count: prompt. Then use a predefined key to invoke the 'replace' command. Type the search and replacement strings when Rally prompts you and press KPEnter to start the replacement.
You can use the 'global_replace' command to perform substitutions throughout your work area.
To use the 'replace' command:
1. Invoke the 'replace' command. Rally displays the Find string: prompt.
2. Enter the existing string that you want to replace.
3. Press the KPEnter key to indicate that you have finished entering the string. Rally now displays the Replace string: prompt.
4. Enter the string you want to appear in your text.
5. Press the appropriate arrow key to set the direction of the search. To search in the forward direction, press the down arrow key. To search in the reverse direction, press the up arrow key.
6. Press the KPEnter key to indicate that you have finished entering the string. Rally now displays the new string on the screen.
The search and replacement strings remain in effect until you change them by issuing another command that involves search strings or replacement strings.
Alias: replace
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'clear case_sensitive' command to turn off case sensitivity. The 'toggle case_sensitive' command changes the current case sensitivity setting.
By default, case sensitivity is off when you start a Rally session.
When case sensitivity is on, Rally differentiates between uppercase and lowercase letters when using the 'find', 'delete find', 'replace', and 'global_replace' commands. For example, if you type JOANNE, when case sensitivity is on, Rally does not match that entry with Joanne or JoAnne. When case sensitivity is turned off, all three entries are considered to be identical.
This command does not affect query-by-example.
Alias: setcasesens
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'clear auto_fill' command to turn off automatic fill mode. The 'toggle auto_fill' command changes the current automatic fill mode setting.
By default, Rally turns this setting on whenever you enter the screen editing context. In menu and form/report contexts, the default setting is OFF.
When automatic filling is not in effect, Rally allows you to move the cursor with arrow keys only where text or specific space characters are present. For example, to move the cursor to the right on an empty line, you must use the space bar rather than the right arrow key.
When automatic filling is in effect, you can use the arrow keys to move the cursor anywhere on the screen or window. As you press the arrow keys, RALLY allows you to move to character cells where there is no text. If you enter new text where there is no text to the left of the cursor, Rally inserts spaces to fill in the area between the left margin or last character and the current cursor position. This feature helps you format menus and form/reports because you can easily place text in different locations on the screen or window.
Alias: setdrawmode
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'clear overstrike' command to turn off overstrike mode. The 'toggle overstrike' command changes the current automatic fill mode setting.
When you start a Rally session, the state of overstrike mode (on or off) is determined by the key definition file. The EDT- and WPS-style key definition files supplied with Rally turn on overstrike mode.
When your Rally session is set to overstrike mode, you can enter a new character simply by typing over the one that the cursor is on. Any characters that remain on the screen to the right of the cursor are still part of the field contents.
If overstrike mode is not set, the characters you type are inserted into the text, pushing over the characters that are to the right of the cursor.
Alias: setovertype
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'clear word_wrap' command to turn off word-wrap mode. The 'toggle word_wrap' command changes the current word-wrap mode setting.
By default, word wrap is off when you start a Rally session, as determined by the default key definition file.
When word wrapping is in effect, Rally breaks long lines of text between words and puts the remainder of the text on another line. If word wrapping is not in effect, the remainder of text lines that are too long to fit on the screen do not appear.
If word wrap is not in effect, you must explicitly end a line and start a new one.
Word wrapping occurs at a specific point on a line. This point depends on the current environment:
1. In ADL procedures, word wrapping always occurs whenever the text on a line exceeds 80 characters. Window size does not affect the word wrap point.
2. In screen editing of form/reports and menus, the word wrap point occurs whenever the line exceeds the width of the object (form/report text area or menu text area).
3. When editing a multi-line form/report field, word wrapping occurs when the width of the field is exceeded.
Alias: setpwrtype
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
When case sensitivity is on, Rally differentiates between upper- and lower-case letters with the 'find', 'delete find', or 'replace' commands. For example, if you type JOANNE, when case sensitivity is on, Rally does not match that entry with Joanne or JoAnne. When case sensitivity is turned off, all three entries are considered to be identical.
This command does not affect query-by-example.
Alias: clrcasesens
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'toggle overstrike' command switches back and forth between overstrike and insert modes. Use the 'set overstrike' command to turn on overstrike mode. The 'clear overstrike' command turns off overstrike mode. When your Rally session is set to overstrike mode, you can enter a new character simply by typing over the one that the cursor is on. Any characters that remain on the screen to the right of the cursor are still part of the field contents.
If overstrike mode is not set, the characters you type are inserted into the text.
You can use overstrike mode to change numbers or letters in the middle of text without having to type the item over again.
When you start a Rally session, the state of overstrike mode (on or off) is determined by the key definition file. The EDT- and WPS-style key definition files supplied with Rally turn on overstrike mode.
Alias: togovertype
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the 'set word_wrap' command to turn on word wrapping. The 'clear word_wrap' command turns off word wrapping.
When you start a Rally session, the state of word wrapping (on or off) is determined by the key definition file. The EDT- and WPS-style key definition files supplied with Rally turn off word wrapping.
When word wrapping is in effect, Rally breaks long lines of text between words and puts the remainder of the text on another line. If word wrapping is not in effect, the remainder of text lines that are too long to fit on the screen do not appear.
If word wrap is not in effect, you must explicitly end a line and start a new one.
Word wrapping occurs at a specific point on a line. This point depends on the current environment:
o In ADL procedures, word wrapping always occurs whenever the text on a line exceeds 80 characters. Window size does not affect the word wrap point.
o In screen editing of form/reports and menus, the word wrap point occurs whenever the line exceeds the width of the object (form/report text area or menu text area).
o When editing a multiline form/report field, word wrapping occurs when the width of the field is exceeded.
Alias: togpwrtype
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The turtle mode commands are:
o 'highlight turtle'
o 'draw_line turtle'
o 'undraw_line turtle'
Alias: turtleclear
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'highlight to_mark' command has no effect if there is no mark set.
The 'highlight to_mark' command does not overwrite the text that is being highlighted. However, you cannot highlight line-drawing characters.
When you use the 'highlight to_mark' command to highlight an area, the highlighting becomes a permanent part of the menu or form/report and appears on the screen when the menu or form/report is displayed. Depending on the type of printer you have, some highlight types, such as underlining, will appear on the output.
To highlight an entire line of the menu or form/report you are designing:
1. Invoke the 'set highlight_type' command, followed by an equal sign (=) and the kind of highlight you want: underline, reverse video, blink, or bold. If you do not specify a highlight type, Rally prompts you with a list of the types; move the cursor to the right of the type you want to select. Type an X beside each of your highlight choices. Invoke the 'finish action' command.
2. Move the cursor to the beginning of the line that you want to highlight.
3. Use the 'set mark' command to mark that location.
4. Move the cursor to the end of the line.
5. Invoke the 'highlight to_mark' command. Rally highlights the entire line.
Rally provides three alternative ways to remove a highlight type:
o Use 'set highlight_type=none'.
o Use 'set highlight_type' followed by 'finish action'.
o Use 'set highlight_type', press KPEnter, and delete the X characters on the prompt list.
Alias: hightomark
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
After you have entered the 'highlight turtle' command, each time you move the cursor, Rally either applies highlighting to the cursor character or removes the highlighting. You can continue to move the cursor down, up, to the left, and right to apply or remove highlighting.
When you finish applying or removing the highlighting, either invoke another turtle mode command ('draw_line turtle' or 'undraw_line turtle') to continue working in turtle mode or issue the 'finish turtle' command to leave turtle mode.
When you use the 'highlight turtle' command to add highlighting, the highlighting becomes a permanent part of the menu or form/report and appears on the screen when the menu or form/report is displayed. Depending on the type of printer you have, some highlight types, such as underlining, will appear on the output.
To add highlighting to your menu or form/report:
1. Invoke the 'set highlight_type' command, followed by an equal sign (=) and the kind of highlight you want: underline, reverse video, blink, or bold. If you do not specify a highlight type, Rally prompts you with a list of the types; move the cursor to the right of the type you want to select. Type an "x" beside each of your highlight choices. Invoke the 'finish action' command.
2. Move the cursor to the character you want to highlight.
3. Invoke the 'highlight turtle' command. Rally applies the highlighting to the current cursor location.
4. Continue to move the cursor to each character that you want highlighted.
Rally provides three alternative ways to remove a highlight type:
o Use 'set highlight_type=none'.
o Use 'set highlight_type' followed by 'finish action'.
o Use 'set highlight_type', press KPEnter, and delete the X characters on the prompt list.
Alias: turtlehl
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To select one or more highlight types using the 'set highlight_ type' command, invoke the 'set highlight_type' command, followed by an equal sign (=), and the type or types of highlight you want: underline, reverse video, blink, or bold. For example:
Command: set highlight_type=blink
If you do not specify a highlight type, Rally prompts you with a list of the types: move the cursor to the right of the type you want to select. Type an "x" beside each of your highlight choices. Invoke the 'finish action' command.
You can select a combination of two or more types of highlighting. For example:
Command: set highlight_type=(bold,underline)
The highlight types you select remain in effect until you change the selection or end your Rally session. Rally provides three ways to remove a highlight type:
o Use set highlight_type=none.
o Use 'set highlight_type' followed by 'finish action'.
o Use 'set highlight_type' and press KPEnter twice.
Line-drawing characters (solid lines) are not highlighted in the Rally screen editor.
Alias: hightypeset
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'undraw_line to_mark' command has no effect if there is no mark in your file.
To erase a line of line-drawing characters:
1. Move the cursor to the beginning of the line or line segment you want to erase.
2. Use the 'set mark' command to mark that position.
3. Move the cursor to the end of the line or line segment.
4. Invoke the 'undraw_line to_mark' command. Rally removes all the line-drawing characters between the two points.
Use the 'draw_line to_mark' command to add line-drawing characters to menus and form/reports.
Alias: uldtomark
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Invoking the 'undraw_line turtle' command puts your Rally session in turtle mode.
After you have entered the 'undraw_line turtle' command, each time you move the cursor, Rally replaces the line-drawing character at the cursor location with a space. You can continue to move the cursor down, up, to the left, and right to remove line-drawing characters.
When you finish removing the line-drawing characters, you can invoke another turtle mode command ('draw_line turtle' or 'highlight turtle') to continue working in turtle mode, or issue the 'finish turtle' command to leave turtle mode.
Use the 'draw_line turtle' command to apply line-drawing characters to your menu or form/report.
Alias: uldturtle
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'draw_line to_mark' command has no effect if there is no mark in your text.
When line-drawing characters pass through boilerplate text, they overwrite the text. There is no way to retrieve this text (except by using a quit command to end the editing session). Make sure you position the lines outside any boilerplate text that appears on your menu or form/report.
Line-drawing characters become permanent elements of the boilerplate and appear each time the menu or form/report is displayed.
To draw a single line, issue the 'set mark' command at one end of the proposed line, move the cursor to the other end, and issue the 'draw_line to_mark' command.
To apply a rectangular perimeter to your menu or form/report, follow these steps:
1. Move the cursor to the upper left-hand corner of the rectangle.
2. Use the 'set mark' command to mark that corner.
3. Move the cursor to the lower right corner of the rectangle.
4. Invoke the 'draw_line to_mark' command. Rally creates a rectangle that connects the two points with line-drawing characters.
You can use the 'undraw_line to_mark', 'undraw_line turtle', 'delete character', or 'delete line' commands to remove line draw characters from the menu or form/report you are editing. You can also set your Rally session to overstrike mode and type over the line-drawing characters with spaces or text to remove them.
Alias: ldtomark
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
When line-drawing characters pass through boilerplate text, they overwrite the text. There is no way to retrieve this text (except by using a 'quit application' command to end the editing session). Make sure you position the line-drawing characters outside any boilerplate text that appears on your menu or form/report.
Line-drawing characters become permanent elements of the boilerplate and appear each time the menu or form/report is displayed.
Invoking the 'draw_line turtle' command puts your Rally session in turtle mode.
After you have entered the 'draw_line turtle' command, each time you move the cursor, Rally applies a line-drawing character to the cursor location. You can continue to move the cursor down, up, to the left, and/or right to add line-drawing characters.
When you finish adding the line-drawing characters, you can invoke another turtle mode command ('undraw_line turtle' or 'highlight turtle') to continue working in turtle mode, or issue the 'finish turtle' command to leave turtle mode.
You can use the 'undraw_line turtle', 'delete character', or 'delete line' commands to remove line draw characters from the menu or form/report you are editing. You can also set your Rally session to overstrike mode and type over the line-drawing characters with spaces or text to remove them.
Alias: turtleld
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
You use the arrow keys to move the boundary lines. After moving the lines, press the KPEnter key to terminate the 'shrink window' command.
The smallest Rally window holds only a single character.
To decrease the size of a Rally window:
1. Invoke the 'shrink window' command.
2. Press an arrow key to move the boundary line toward the center of the window. To move the top boundary line, press the up arrow key. The Left Arrow key moves the left boundary, the right arrow key moves the right boundary, and the down arrow key moves the bottom boundary.
3. Repeat the previous step until the window is the size that you want it. Each time you press the down arrow or up arrow key, the window boundary moves one line toward the center. When you press the left arrow or Right Arrow key, the window boundary moves one column toward the center.
4. Press the KPEnter key when you have finished moving the boundary lines to set the window size at its current dimensions.
While you are shrinking the window, the text remains stationary. As the window size decreases, some text might be covered up as the boundary lines close in. After you press KPEnter to establish the new window size, Rally scrolls the window to place the current cursor position in the visible portion.
After the window is resized, Rally may reformat a form/report to display fewer records per page.
Alias: compresswdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To set up boundaries for a window:
1. Invoke the 'mark window' command.
2. Use the arrow keys to move the cursor to the location where you want to place one corner of the window.
3. Press the KPEnter key to mark this corner.
4. Now move the cursor to a point diagonally opposite the mark you have just set. This point defines the opposite corner of the window.
5. Press the KPEnter key again to mark this opposite corner. Rally displays the boundary lines on the screen.
You can start with any corner of the window as long as the second mark is diagonally opposite from the first mark.
Alias: definewdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To increase the size of a Rally window:
1. Invoke the 'grow window' command.
2. Press an arrow key to move the boundary line away from the center of the window. To move the top boundary line, press the up arrow key. The Left Arrow key moves the left boundary, the right arrow key moves the right boundary, and the down arrow key moves the bottom boundary.
3. Repeat the previous step until the window is the size that you want it. Each time you press the down arrow or up arrow key, the window boundary moves one line away from the center. When you press the left arrow or right arrow key, the window boundary moves one column away from the center.
4. Press the KPEnter key when you have finished moving the boundary lines to set the window size at its current dimensions.
Alias: expandwdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
When you issue the 'maximize window' command, Rally immediately expands the window size to occupy the entire terminal screen.
The 'maximize window' command has the same effect as the 'restore window' command only when the original size of the window is the same as the full screen size.
After the window is resized, Rally may reformat a form/report to display more records per page.
Alias: explodewdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
If the window is already the full screen size, the 'move window' command has no effect.
To move a window:
1. Invoke the 'move window' command.
2. Use the arrow keys to move the window to the new location. Each time you press the down arrow or up arrow key, the window moves down or up one line. Each time you press the left arrow or right arrow key, the window moves one column to the left or right.
3. Press the KPEnter key when you have finished moving the window.
Alias: movewdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The 'restore window' command negates the effect that any of the following commands might have had on the window:
o 'grow window'
o 'maximize window'
o 'move window'
o 'shrink window'
The 'restore window' command has the same effect as the 'maximize window' command only when the original size of the window is the same as the full screen size.
If the 'restore window' command causes a window to shrink, Rally scrolls the window to place the current cursor position in the visible portion.
After a window is resized, Rally may reformat a form/report to display more or fewer records per page.
Alias: resizewdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Use the arrow keys to determine the direction of the scrolling. Each time you press the down arrow or up arrow key, the text scrolls one line. Each time you press the left arrow or right arrow key, the text on the current cursor line moves one column to the right or left.
To scroll a task window:
1. Issue the 'scroll window' command.
2. Press the arrow keys that will enable you to view the material that is not currently visible in the window.
3. Press the KPEnter key when you have finished scrolling.
Note that Rally automatically scrolls windows to place the current cursor position in the visible portion. Thus, when you are scrolling side-to-side, Rally might reposition the text when you press KPEnter.
Alias: scrollwdw
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To define a macro:
1. Invoke the 'define macro' command by pressing a key sequence associated with the command.
2. Rally prompts you for a macro number. Assign the macro any number between 0 and 29, inclusive. Then press KPEnter. For example:
Macro number: 1
Be sure that no other macro in your current Rally session has the same number. If you specify a number that is currently assigned to a macro, Rally overwrites the existing macro with the new one. After you press KPEnter, Rally returns you to your original location on the screen.
3. Invoke the series of commands and keystrokes that you want to include in the macro. Rally executes these commands and keystrokes and records them in the macro.
4. When you are finished entering the commands and keystrokes that make up the macro, invoke the 'define macro' command to end the macro definition. (There is no confirmation or change in the screen appearance, but the macro definition is terminated and saved.)
Use the 'write macros' or 'write named_macro' command to save macros for use in later Rally sessions. Then use the 'read macros' or 'read named_macro' command to read saved macros into your Rally session. The 'macro name' command enables you to perform a saved named macro without having to read it into the macro buffer.
Alias: defmacro
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
You can also use predefined function keys to run macros 1 through 8.
You can repeat a macro by using the 'repeat' command, provided that you use a key or key sequence to invoke the 'macro number' command.
Alias:
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
To execute a macro using the 'macro name' command, the macro must have been stored using the 'write named_macro' command.
Alias: exemacf
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Follow these steps to load a macro file into the macro buffer:
1. At the Command: prompt, type the 'read macros' command and the name of the file to copy into the macro buffer. For example:
Command: read macros mymacros.rgm
If you do not provide a file name, Rally displays the File name: prompt. For example:
Command: read macros Filename: mymacros.rgm
2. Press the KPEnter key. If the file is found, Rally puts a copy of the file contents into the macro buffer. All macros are now ready for use during your current Rally session.
If you use the 'read macros' command when you already have macros loaded in your current Rally session, some macros might be overwritten. For example, suppose you have defined five macros and assigned them numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Now you want to read in a macro file that contains three macros. When those macros were created, they were assigned numbers 4, 5, and 6. After Rally processes your 'read macros' command, you will have six macros: numbers 1, 2, and 3 will be those that were in the macro buffer before you invoked the command; numbers 4, 5, and 6 will be those that were read in as a result of the command.
You can use the 'read macros' command to toggle between groups of macros. In some applications, you might have more than 30 macros that you want to use. You can divide the macros into two groups and alternate between them.
Contrast this command with the 'read named_macro' command, which reads in individual macros saved with the 'write named_macro' command.
Alias: loadmacros
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Alias:
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
Follow these steps to write a macro to a file:
1. At the Command: prompt, type the 'write named_macro' command, the macro number, and the name of the file into which the macro buffer will be copied. For example:
Command: write named_macro 2 mymacros.rgm
If you do not provide a macro number or file name, Rally prompts you for this information. For example,
Command: write named_macro Macro number: 2 Filename: mymacros.rgm
2. Press the KPEnter key.
Rally macro files have a default file type of .RGM. When you write a macro from the macro buffer to an external file, the macro remains in the macro buffer of your current Rally session.
You can use the 'read named_macro' command to read into the macro buffer individual macros that have been saved in files by the 'write named_macro' command. If you want to use a macro without copying it into the macro buffer, use the 'macro name' command. For more information, see the 'macro name'.
Alias: mactofile
[end]

Exit message=RETURN Full Screen=GOLD-X Top=GOLD-T Next page=NEXT SCREEN Prev page=PREV SCREEN Bottom=GOLD-B
The contents of the macro buffer remain the same after you issue the 'write macros' command. Rally does not delete the macros from your current session. However, you can now define new macros and assign them the same numbers since you have a copy of the old macros.
Follow these steps to write the contents of the macro buffer to a file:
1. At the Command: prompt, type the 'write macros' command and the name of the file into which the macro buffer will be copied. For example:
Command: write macros mymacros.rgm
If you do not provide a file name, Rally displays the File name: prompt. For example:
Command: write macros Filename: mymacros.rgm
2. Press the KPEnter key.
Alias: savemacros
[end]

MANTENIMIENTO DE TABLAS
AÑADIR,MODIFICAR,ELIMINAR
Estos procesos permiten la modificación de las tablas de códigos usadas en el sistema SAIC. Para esto es necesario utilizar una serie de comandos los cuales son los siguientes:
Función Deseada Procedimiento
Añadir ó Insertar Para insertar información a la tabla debera presionar la tecla {Insert Here}. Esta coloca una linea en blanco en la pantalla para la entrada de los datos. El espacio en blanco se colocara una fila abajo de la posicion actual del cursor. Siempre que desee insertar informació en la tabla debera utilizar esta función.
Eliminar ó Borrar Para eliminar records de una tabla debera colocar el cursor sobre la fila deseada y luego oprimir la tecla {Remove}.
Modificar ó Actualizar Para actualizar información en la tabla puede moverse atravez de las filas utilizando las flechas provistas en el teclado. Si desea moverse entre campos puede utilizar la tecla {Tab}. Una vez sobre el campo la información puede ser cambiada.
Busqueda de records en la Tabla
En estas pantallas se permite la busqueda de filas o conjunto de datos basados en información entrada en campos particulares. Para lograr esta busqueda se utilizara la tecla {Find}. Al oprimir esta los campos presentados en pantalla son borrados permitiendo la entrada de las caracteristicas para la busqueda. Un ejemplo de este tipo de busqueda seria los siguiente:
1. Ubicado en cualquier de los campos en la pantalla presione el icono {Buscar record}. Esto limpia los campos en la pantalla.
2. Ubique el cursor utilizando la tecla {Tab} sobre el campo que desea utilizar para hacer la busqueda.
3. Entre la ocurrencia que desea buscar, ejemplo Jorge en el campo de nombre.
4. Presione la tecla { F9 }.
5. El sistema le presentara todas aquellas filas en la tabla que tengan como nombre Jorge.
Esto podra hacerlo con uno o más campos presentados en la pantalla.
Teclas Utilizadas para Navegar en la Aplicación
Flecha Arriba - Cursor Arriba Flecha Abajo - Cursor Abajo Next Screen - Proxima pagina Prev Screen - Pagina anterior PF1 y Flecha Arriba - Comienzo de la tabla PF1 y Flecha Abajo - Final de la tabla Cancel - Salir sin salvar F12 o Backspace - Campo previo Help - Ayuda en linea 9 (teclado numérico) - Proximo Bloque 5 y 9 (teclado numérico) - Bloque Previo Remove - Borrar filas PF1 y Remove - Recuperar fila borrada
Aquellas funciones que requieren más de una tecla, solo tendra que presionar la primera una sola vez y luego la segunda tecla.
Para imprimir otro código Presione {F12} o {BS}. Para terminar presione {Cancel}.

INFORMACION ADICIONAL SOBRE EL PROCESO DE TRANSFERENCIAS
Oprima {NextScr} o {PrevScr} para moverse a través del texto y {Espacio} para finalizar con esta ayuda.
1. Se procede a transferir cuando todos los miembros del núcleo de servicio se mudan. Si solo una parte de los miembros del núcleo se mudan procede un cambio y los mismos deberán solicitar en la nueva oficina local.
2. Se transfiere una familia cuando todos los miembros incluídos en los núcleos de servicio se mudan. Si algún miembro de la Composición Familiar no pertenece al (los) servicio(s) que serán transferidos el técnico procederá a removerlo de la Composición Familiar y efectuará el proceso de Transferencia de Familia.
3. Se transfiere un servicio cuando todos los miembros del núcleo del servicio se mudan. Si el encargado del servicio es responsable de un servicio o más todos los servicios asociados a éste serán transferidos.
4. Cuando uno ó mas miembros del servicio a transferir pertenecen además a un servicio que no será transferido, el administrador del caso procederá a remover el(los) miembro(s) del servicio que se queda antes de transferir. Es su responsabilidad correr la determinación de elegibilidad.
5. El sistema efectuará automáticamente el ajuste del período de certificación. Este se ejecutará al momento de completar la transferencia.
6. Los casos Cerrados o Rechazados no serán transferidos. No obstante, cuando se va a transferir un Servicio Activo los servicios asociados al mismo encargado serán transferidos independientemente del estatus (PENDAUTO, PENDELEG, PENDREVI, CERRADO o RECHAZO). De tener el caso reclamación o retroactivo pendiente se evaluará para determinar si procede la transferencia en ese momento.
7. Cuando el servicio activo a transferirse incluye miembros del Servicio Cerrado o Rechazado la aplicación removerá los miembros automáticamente de estos Servicios.
8. Cuando una persona radica solicitud en una nueva oficina y los antecedentes indican estatus cerrado con reclamación/retroactivo se evaluará de acuerdo a las normas si procede solicitar la transferencia del caso a través del SAIC y el expediente con la información de la reclamación/retroactivo.

Descalificados: - Marcar el campo Descalificado con una "X" causara que permita el acceso a la parte de abajo de la pantalla donde se encuentra la información de desscalificación. - El funcionamiento de las teclas en esta sección de la pantalla será la siguiente:
Tecla Función
{Insert} Para añadir un récord de descalificación.
{ End } Para seleccionar un récord de descalificación.
Flecha Arriba Para mover hacia arriba el cursor entre los récords de descalificación.
Flecha Abajo Para mover hacia abajo el cursor entre los récords de descalificación existentes.
{Help} Para que el sistema presente una pantalla de ayuda ya sea de un campo o de la pantalla.
{ F8 } Para regresar a la pantalla anterior sin guardar los cambios hechos en la pantalla.

Registro de Empleo:

Tecla Función
{9} Para mover el cursor entre los grupos de la pantalla, esto es, Licencias, Eperiencias, Idiomas y Cursos Adietramientos.
{Return} Para mover el cursor entre los campos de un grupo.
{Insert} Para añadir un récord.
Flecha Arriba Para mover hacia arriba el cursor entre los récords de los grupos.
Flecha Abajo Para mover hacia abajo el cursor entre los récords de los grupos.
{Help} Para que el sistema presente una pantalla de ayuda ya sea de un campo o de la pantalla.
{ F8 } Para regresar a la pantalla anterior sin guardar los cambios hechos en la pantalla.
{ F9 } Para salir de la pantalla y guardar los cambios hechos en la pantalla.
